Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you stands a vigilant woman in a crimson-crested helm and desert-worn hauberk, her posture rigid but her eyes sharp with purpose.

“Halt! This is the domain of the Ruby Guard. I am Commander Shira al-Garnet—loyal to Qasaria, loyal to Rafiq, and loyal to order above all. State your business. There is little patience for loiterers or would-be spies in my city.”

Option.text: I wish to serve the city, Commander.
Your reputation precedes you. Who are you, truly?
What do you know of the Council of Jewels?
Any work for someone who can handle themselves?
Tell me more about yourself, Commander.
I’m just passing through.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira’s jaw sets. “I was not born to command. My name was a stain in Qasaria for years—my platoon was blamed for a failed defense at the River of Stones. I clawed back my honor in the dunes, bled for every officer’s respect. Rafiq al-Ruby saw more than a scapegoat. He named me Commander, not for my lineage, but for my resolve.
Do not mistake loyalty for blindness. Qasaria is riddled with those who crave power, not peace.”

Option.text: Rafiq must trust you greatly.
Do you trust the other councilmembers?
Your strength inspires loyalty.
Can you offer work for someone of integrity?

Dialogue.NPCText: “Rafiq al-Ruby is a good man, even if his ideals sometimes cloud his judgment. He stands for Qasaria as it was—proud, independent, not some puppet of Magincia or Nujel’m. He gave me a second chance; I will not let him—or this city—fall while I draw breath.”

Option.text: And the others on the council?
Let’s discuss more pressing matters.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira scowls, her tone low.

“The Council of Jewels. Five princes and princesses, each sharper than a scorpion’s sting. Safiya al-Sapphire cares only for her profit margins—she’d trade Qasaria’s soul for the right price. Karim al-Emerald? I trust him less than a glass blade in battle; he plants spies where my soldiers should be.
Yasmin al-Topaz locks herself away with relics and secrets. Omar al-Onyx is loyal… until his next arena champion tempts him otherwise.
But this city stands because some of us still value duty over coin or magic. Rafiq and I are among the last.”

Option.text: You sound beset on all sides.
Are you at odds with Yasmin’s mystics?
Do you have work rooting out these spies?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira’s voice is cold.
“I do not trust magic—not since I watched a sorcerous betrayal cost us a hundred lives at the River of Stones. Yasmin and her circle claim to serve the city, but their secrets breed more secrets. Let them study relics and desert omens, but I will keep Qasaria’s streets safe the old-fashioned way.”

Option.text: I respect your caution. How can I help?
Magic can be a tool for good, if kept in check.
Your distrust is noted. Perhaps I should be going.

Dialogue.NPCText: Shira nods curtly. “Then move along. Qasaria’s streets are not a playground. But if you wish to prove your loyalty, come back with purpose.”

Option.text: On second thought, have you any work?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira lowers her voice, scanning the shadows.

“Listen closely. Karim al-Emerald and Safiya al-Sapphire have been seeding my barracks with spies—servants, scribes, even supposed recruits. My Ruby Guard bleeds discipline, but loyalty cannot be taken for granted. I need an outsider to confirm my suspicions. Someone not yet tainted by council intrigue.

Find three suspects among the barracks—speak with each, uncover their true allegiances, and return with proof. But beware: some may try to bribe or threaten you. Choose carefully who you accuse. If you’re discovered aiding Karim or Safiya, do not expect my gratitude.”

Option.text: I will expose the traitors, Commander.
Why do you trust me with this?
If I help you, will Rafiq reward me?
What if the spies are innocent?
This is not my fight.

Dialogue.NPCText: “You’re new blood. Not yet tangled in the Council’s web—or at least, I hope so. Outsiders see what my loyalists cannot. And frankly, if you betray me, I’d rather know now than later.”

Option.text: I will prove myself worthy.
Maybe you’re right to be paranoid…
On second thought, I’ll pass.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira grins for the first time.
“Rafiq rewards courage and loyalty. Prove yourself, and you will earn a favor from the Ruby Prince himself. But cross me—or play both sides—and you may find Qasaria’s gates less welcoming.”

Option.text: I accept your terms.
Sounds risky. I’ll decline.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Then bring me proof of their innocence, and I will judge accordingly. I punish only traitors. But remember—every hour wasted gives Karim’s agents more time to burrow deeper.”

Option.text: I will investigate with care.
I cannot risk accusing innocents.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira hands you a wax-sealed dossier stamped with the mark of the Ruby Guard.

“This contains the names and quarters of three suspects. Use your judgment—interrogate, persuade, bribe, or spy as you see fit. Bring me evidence: tokens, confessions, or coded missives. Choose your allies wisely; my gratitude is reserved for those who serve Qasaria, not her enemies.

Go—and trust no one in the barracks. Not even me.”

Option.text: Understood. I will return with answers.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira folds her arms, eyeing you warily.

“Few ask who I was before I wore this helm. You’re either bold—or looking for leverage. But fine. You want to know who I am? Listen, and listen well. There are truths in this city that weigh heavier than plate armor.”

Option.text: I listen to understand, not to judge.
You clearly earned your rank. I respect that.
Is this another tale of a fallen noble turned patriot?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“I was born in the gutters of Old Qasaria—before the city rose atop sandglass towers and silken dreams. My mother was a stonemason. My father, a soldier who never came home. I learned early how to fight for my meals, and later, how to fight for others.”

She pauses. “When Rafiq marched on the renegades of the Crimson Divide, I volunteered. They said gutter-born scum couldn’t wear a uniform. I made them eat those words… with bloodied teeth.”

Option.text: That sounds like a hard road.
And now you command the Ruby Guard.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“I earned every stripe by bleeding beside my comrades. But command isn’t just shouting orders and polishing steel. It’s keeping weak men strong and strong men honest.
That’s where I differ from Omar al-Onyx. He trains champions. I raise defenders.”

Option.text: Sounds like you’ve no love for the arena.
Have you ever fought in it?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The Sands of Blood? Glorified slaughter. Entertainment for bored nobles and criminals. Real battles don’t give you cheering crowds. Just dirt, screaming, and regret.”

She grimaces. “Omar drinks applause like wine. But out there, on the dunes? Applause doesn’t stop arrows.”

Option.text: That’s fair. I’ve seen real battles myself.
Still, arena fighters are brave too.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira’s lips curl in a rare smirk.
“Once. Long ago. Before the Guard. I fought under the name *Scorpion’s Dagger*—to pay for my mother’s debts. Three wins, no deaths. I walked away before the crowd could claim my soul.”
She leans in. “Don’t tell Omar. He’d challenge me to a rematch.”

Option.text: Your secret is safe with me.
Maybe you still have some fight left in you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Careful, soldier. Flattery smells a lot like provocation. You don’t want to see what the Ruby Guard trains for when the crowds aren’t watching.”
She narrows her eyes. “Unless you’re *that* bored.”

Option.text: Let’s keep this friendly… for now.
Maybe I do want a sparring session.
Option.action: SendMessage:She nods toward the practice yard...

Dialogue.NPCText: “They are. But bravery without purpose is just noise. Qasaria needs discipline, not spectacle. Still, I don’t begrudge those who survive the pit. Just don’t mistake the sand for the battlefield.”

Option.text: We see differently, but I respect your view.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Not many outsiders ask questions like these. Fewer still listen. I’ll remember that.”
Shira looks away, then back.
“If you truly wish to serve Qasaria, understand this: loyalty isn’t given—it’s earned. Come back when you’re ready to prove yours.”

Option.text: You have my word. I’ll return with purpose.
I already walk that path.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Then go. Watch the streets. Feel their pulse. The rot spreads from beneath the silken towers. The sooner you see it, the sooner you’ll understand why I trust blades more than words.”

Option.text: Then I’ll return with more than words.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Hard roads forge sharp blades. Mine was crooked, bloody, and full of regret. I’ve buried friends. Burned bridges. Broken my word—once. Never again.”
She looks away.
“The day I watched my mentor fall in the ambush at Echo Dune, I vowed I’d make Qasaria stronger than the desert that devours us. Every spy rooted, every wall reinforced—that’s my penance.”

Option.text: Sounds like you’ve paid your dues.
You carry a heavy burden.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira’s voice turns to steel.
“Careful. Your tongue might get you thrown from the barracks before your boots leave the gate. I may be loyal to Qasaria—but I don’t suffer fools in my ranks.”

Option.text: My apologies. That was uncalled for.
Then let’s keep things professional.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Shira cracks her neck. “Fine. Meet me at the Ruby Guard’s sparring circle at dusk. No spells. No theatrics. Just steel.”
[A new sidequest becomes available at the sparring arena after 6PM game time]

Option.text: I’ll be there.
Option.action: SendMessage:A sparring session is now unlocked at the Ruby Guard training ground.
